--- title: "quarto introduction" author: "Tony Duan" execute: warning: false error: false format: html: toc: true toc-location: right code-fold: show code-tools: true code-block-bg: true code-block-border-left: "#31BAE9" code-copy: true css: hscroll.css --- # install quarto ## install quarto CLI https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/ ## install quarto package ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("quarto") ``` ::: # check quarto version ## in Terminal ::: {.cell filename='Terminal'} ```{.bash .cell-code} quarto check ``` ::: ![](images/paste-1.png){width="600"} ## in R ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(quarto) quarto_version() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] '1.8.25' ``` ::: ::: quarto location ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} quarto_path() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "/Applications/quarto/bin/quarto" ``` ::: ::: # quarto code chunk ## R ```{{R}} version ``` ## Python ```{{python}} import sys print(sys.version) ``` ## Bash ```{{bash}} echo "foo" ``` # calling variable between R and Python There are R variable: r_var and Python version:python_var ```{{r}} r_var=111 ``` ::: {.cell} ::: ```{{python}} python_var=222 ``` ::: {.cell} ::: ::: panel-tabset ## calling python variable in R ```{{python}} r.r_var ``` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 111.0 ``` ::: ::: ## calling R variable in Python ```{{r}} library(reticulate) py$python_var ``` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 222 ``` ::: ::: ::: # quarto code chunk option ## in YAML header ``` yaml --- title: "My Document" execute: echo: false jupyter: python3 --- ``` - eval: Evaluate the code chunk (if false, just echos the code into the output). - echo: Include the source code in output. - output: Include the results of executing the code in the output (true, false, or asis to indicate that the output is raw markdown and should not have any of Quarto's standard enclosing markdown). - warning: Include warnings in the output. - error: Evaluate the code chunk (if false, just echos the code into the output). - include: Catch all for preventing any output (code or results) from being included (e.g. include: false suppresses all output from the code block). ## in code chunk ::: {.cell} ```{.bash .cell-code} #| eval: false ``` ::: # code chunk name `{r filename='code chunk name sample'}` ::: {.cell filename='code chunk name sample'} ```{.r .cell-code} a=1 a ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 ``` ::: ::: # Rmarkdown ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} *italics* and _italics_ **bold** and __bold__ superscript^2^ ~~strikethrough~~ [link](www.rstudio.com) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} *italics* ``` ::: *italics* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} **bold** ``` ::: **bold** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} superscript^2^ ``` ::: superscript^2^ ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ~~strikethrough~~ ``` ::: ~~strikethrough~~ ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} `highlight` ``` ::: `highlight` ## link ```` [link](www.rstudio.com) ```` [link](www.rstudio.com) ## tab ```` ::: {.panel-tabset} ## Tab 1 This is tab 1 ## Tab 2 This is tab 2 ::: ```` ::: panel-tabset ### Tab 1 This is tab 1 ### Tab 2 This is tab 2 ::: ## column display ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} this column with 40% width ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} this column with 60% width ::: ::: ``` ::: ::::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} this column with 40% width ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} this column with 60% width ::: ::::: # Add a horizontal scroll bar - # Theme in _quarto.yml(for all page) or header(only for this page) ::: {.cell filename='_quarto.yml'} ```{.r .cell-code} theme: light: cosmo dark: [cosmo, theme-dark.scss] ``` ::: source:https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/html-themes.html # Managing Execution ## render a folder or file ::: {.cell filename='Terminal'} ```{.bash .cell-code} quarto render introduction.qmd quarto render subdir/ ``` ::: ## Freeze You can use the freeze option to denote that computational documents should never be re-rendered during a global project render, or alternatively only be re-rendered when their source file changes: in _quarto.yml(for all page) or header(only for this page) ::: {.cell filename='_quarto.yml'} ```{.r .cell-code} execute: freeze: true # never re-render during project render ``` ::: ::: {.cell filename='_quarto.yml'} ```{.r .cell-code} execute: freeze: auto # re-render only when source changes ``` ::: ## Cache You can use the cache option to cache the results of computations (using the knitr cache for R documents, and Jupyter Cache for Jupyter documents): ::: {.cell filename='_quarto.yml'} ```{.r .cell-code} execute: cache: true ``` ::: Note that cache invalidation is triggered by changes in chunk source code (or other cache attributes you’ve defined). You may however need to manually refresh the cache if you know that some other input (or even time) has changed sufficiently to warrant an update. To do this, render either individual files or an entire project using the --cache-refresh option: source:https://quarto.org/docs/projects/code-execution.html ::: {.cell filename='Terminal'} ```{.r .cell-code} quarto render mydoc.qmd --cache-refresh # single doc quarto render --cache-refresh # entire project ``` ::: # add comment ## using giscus comment tool https://giscus.app/ ### step 1 install giscus on github https://github.com/apps/giscus ### step 2 enable GitHub Discussions for your repository ![](images/clipboard-2990658216.png) ### step 3 add script to blog post ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ''' ''' ``` ::: #### step 3b or using comment for all page add into _quarto.yml ::: {.cell filename='_quarto.yml'} ```{.r .cell-code} format: html: include-after-body: - text: ``` ::: # quarto engine Quarto is a multi-language, next generation version of R Markdown from RStudio, with many new features and capabilities ::: panel-tabset ## using R by default, Quarto uses Knitr to execute R code ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} title: "matplotlib demo" format: html: code-fold: true ``` ::: ## using Python when set jupyter: python3 it will run quarto file with python ### First, install jupyter & rpy2 ::: {.cell} ```{.bash .cell-code} pip install jupyter pip install rpy2 ``` ::: ### add engine jupyter: python3 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} --- title: "ggplot2 demo" author: "Norah Jones" date: "5/22/2021" format: html: code-fold: true jupyter: python3 --- ``` ::: Note that when rendering an .ipynb Quarto will not execute the cells within the notebook by default (the presumption being that you have already executed them while editing the notebook) You can also specify this behavior within the notebook’s YAML front matter: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} --- title: "My Notebook" execute: enabled: true --- ``` ::: ### Run R in python code chunk under python environment ::: {.cell} ```{.python .cell-code} %load_ext rpy2.ipython ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.python .cell-code} %%R print(R.version) ``` ::: ::: # quarto output format ::: panel-tabset ## html ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} --- title: "ggplot2 demo" author: "Tony D" date: "5/22/2021" format: html --- ``` ::: ## pdf ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} --- title: "ggplot2 demo" author: "Tony D" date: "5/22/2021" format: pdf --- ``` ::: ## MS words ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} --- title: "ggplot2 demo" author: "Tony D" date: "5/22/2021" format: docx --- ``` ::: ## MS PowerPoint ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} --- title: "ggplot2 demo" author: "Tony D" date: "5/22/2021" format: pptx --- ``` ::: ##
